Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Unifying the Science of Language

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
For generations, uncovering the nature of human language has challenged researchers across a range of disciplines. Breakthrough progress requires a highly multidisciplinary yet integrated research effort, necessitating a new kind of language scientist capable of working across traditional disciplinary boundaries. This IGERT award facilitates the development of such scientists, further developing the Problem-Centered Training approach pioneered at Johns Hopkins. Through the programs Computational and Experimental Tracks, trainees will learn to deploy the diversity of methods and perspectives of linguistics, experimental psychology, computer science, cognitive neuroscience and mathematics in the attack of a single problem in the domain of language. Through an international component, trainees will gain experience in the laboratories of foreign pioneers in multiple disciplines, and will engage in research on languages other than English.

Linguistics has been undergoing a revolutionary transformation, expanding its horizons to embrace the full cognitive science of language. Trainees in this IGERT will, through their graduate work and beyond, play a vital role in completing this transformation, and in bridging a number of fundamental schisms currently dividing language science. Breakthroughs arising from a unified science of language will have major long-term impact on language education. In the short term, scientists trained in the Computational Track will transfer insight from linguistic theory to language engineering, impacting commercial and security technology. Through a suite of special outreach mechanisms targeting not only Ph.D. applicants, but also their faculty mentors and a broader undergraduate population, the program promotes the involvement of underrepresented minorities in scientific research. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since our IGERT grant proposal was written, Artificial Intelligence has become an imminent reality, due largely to the deployment of Deep Neural Networks. What is new is the enormity of the available data for training learning systems and of the computing power to carry out such learning within huge networks. Crucially, the conceptual and technological engines of this revolution were already in place a quarter century ago. They were constructed by cognitive scientists.

The pursuit of deep questions in cognition, cast in a computational form and attacked with mathematics, produced fundamental insights that are now paying unprecedented dividends. Such research continues, much of it directed at a key factor in the pre-eminence of cognition in homo sapiens: human language. The accomplishments of 25 years ago are unlikely to suffice for cracking human language, we believe; the work targeted by our IGERT program aims to provide the insights needed to enable artificial systems built in the coming decades to acquire human language to the degree achieved by every healthy child.

It is imperative that the research fostered by our program also develop fundamental mathematical tools. A top-level goal of our program was to help catalyze the transition of the cognitive science of language into a truly mathematical field. The more pervasive mathematical/computational methods become in cognitive science, the more research will be carried out that has enormous potential payoff in future decades.

This evolution of the cognitive science of language into a unified, mathematically-driven field has been blocked by interdisciplinary chasms isolating it from neighboring, often more mathematically-advanced, disciplines. Six such chasms were targeted in the proposal, and the program made significant progress towards bridging all of them, spawning five new mathematical subfields of cognitive science. The achievements had two facets: directing trainee doctoral research that built the initial cross-disciplinary bridges, and creating the novel type of training needed to enable trainees to carry such interdisciplinary work to completion throughout their careers.

Our aspiration was to mainstream mathematical research within the cognitive science of language, and within the program that ambitious goal was actually achieved. When our IGERT began, mathematical/computational research was the occupation of a few students who arrived in the program with strong formal backgrounds. At the close of the IGERT NSF funding, without exception, students in the program—no matter their level of formal skills upon arrival—regard it as a necessity to pursue mathematical training through coursework and—for the majority of them—through first-hand research experience. Notably, this applies equally to our female trainees and associates, who constitute over half of our students; this is producing a growing stream of strong role models for future female scientists. The new, more mathematical, academic culture is being disseminated beyond the program as trainees carry it to a diversity of cognitive science communities where our graduates are obtaining tenure-track positions.

A few illustrations of the research accomplishments of our trainees in building interdisciplinary bridges:

  • Most people across the globe speak more than one language, and future linguistically-savvy computers will certainly need to. Trainee Lisa Hsin showed how to extend the computational system of an important grammatical theory so that a single unified grammar can produce sentences in multiple languages. She used this to explain surprising data that she analyzed, data showing that early bilingualism can actually accelerate learning: knowledge acquired in one language can transfer to another even where the two languages differ significantly.
